message: I'm doing a (non-CS) PhD with a strong interest in translating my research into a startup after defending. Anyone else following this route? Also, I created a convore group for PhD students if anyone is interested. Cheers!
If it's a high tech startup I think it's a good option but if not you can miss the opportunity

I agree. If your goal is to build yet another social media web application, the relative value of completing (or even starting) a PhD seems questionable. The benefit is for technologies that require significant technical sophistication and exploratory work. I'm interested in the brain-computer interface, which is not really something you can work on in your garage.
what are you going to be studying for your phd?

@rookie coursework has focused on computational models of perception and motor control from a neuroscience perspective. the project i'm starting soon will explore using noninvasive BCI (i.e. EEG) for robotic control.

I’d suggest creating a small start-up project which you think is disposable and do this as a ‘hobby’ to learn the rules of the road before you take on a major project.  Cheaper to make mistakes that way.
Great and you can consider that a disposable learning experience, unless you invent the next consumer internet god :-)

@hashbo that's a great idea and one i've been giving considerable thought to recently. i have a more traditional HN-style startup idea that i've been kicking around, and may actively pursue once the semester winds down.

@bgalbraith sounds like a useful phd for getting into that type of market. do you have embedded electronics experience to build something like that? maybe some side projects in that direction might be a good start. small projects are definitely a great way to go.

I'm dropping out of a nanoengineering phd program to build a web 3.0 Q&A site (tons of overlap, I know). I do research on medical diagnostics and I love it, but the window of opportunity for my web startup open now and it would kill me to spend 3+ more years on a phd when I could have a site up and running within a year.
